section.title: Defining Relative Clauses
section.sectiontitle: Use defining relative clauses to make clear who or what you are talking about. Use them for essential information.
section.text1: Peter and I met a man. He lived in the flat above us.
section.text1a: Peter and I met the man who lived in the flat above us.
section.text2: This is the place. I was born here.
section.text2a: This is the place where I was born.
section.sectiontitle2: We often use that instead of who or which.
section.text3: That's the girl who I want to marry.
section.text3a: That's the girl that I want to marry.
section.text4: It's a type of fruit which you can eat.
section.text4a: It's a type of fruit that you can eat.

section.title: Defining Relative Clauses
section.sectiontitle: When the verb after the relative pronoun has a different subject, we can leave out the relative pronouns who and which.
section.text1: The food which I ate was called tamales.
section.text1a: The food I ate was called tamales.
section.text2: The girl who I spoke to was friendly.
section.text2a: The girl I spoke to was friendly.
